summary: This is an internal FBI email chain from August 16, 2019, regarding media inquiries about the FBI's intention to interview Prince Andrew as part of the Jeffrey Epstein sex trafficking conspiracy investigation. A journalist from The Sun seeks comment, and the FBI's public affairs specialist states they have no comment.

persons.name: Amy J. Thoreson
persons.context: FBI Public Affairs Specialist in New York who forwards a media inquiry about Prince Andrew and the Epstein investigation internally, stating the FBI has no comment.

persons.name: James Beal
persons.context: Journalist for The Sun who emails the FBI's national press office seeking comment on a story that the FBI intends to interview Prince Andrew as part of the Epstein sex trafficking investigation.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: British royal whom the FBI reportedly intends to interview as part of the wider conspiracy investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's sex trafficking operation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Central figure in the sex trafficking operation investigation, to which Prince Andrew is linked as someone the FBI intends to interview.

connections.description: Prince Andrew is mentioned as an individual the FBI intends to interview as part of the wider conspiracy investigation into Epstein's sex trafficking operation.
Journalist Beal contacts the FBI's national press office; Thoreson, an FBI public affairs specialist, responds to the inquiry.

events.title: Media Inquiry Regarding FBI Interview of Prince Andrew
events.description: Journalist James Beal emails the FBI seeking comment on a story that the FBI intends to interview Prince Andrew as part of the Epstein sex trafficking conspiracy investigation.

locations: London, SE1 9GF (registered office of News Corp UK & Ireland Limited)
keyFacts: On August 16, 2019, The Sun journalist James Beal contacted the FBI seeking comment on a story that the FBI intended to interview Prince Andrew regarding the Jeffrey Epstein sex trafficking conspiracy investigation.
The FBI's Public Affairs Specialist in New York, Amy J. Thoreson, responded internally and to the journalist that the FBI had no comment on the matter.
The email indicates the FBI's investigation into Epstein's sex trafficking operation was active and considering interviews with high-profile individuals like Prince Andrew.
The correspondence highlights media interest and the FBI's cautious public communications strategy regarding a sensitive, high-profile investigation.
